1. [MH] Redisplay Menu Help
2. [CH] Chat with the Agent about anything

payload.text:
**Analyzing localization for default alt text and error messages**

I'm figuring out how to handle the default "Entry photo" alt text, which is stored in English but needs to appear localized in the UI without changing the stored data. My plan is to export the default alt constant and map it to translations during rendering in UI components like EntryDetail and MediaGallery, keeping data untouched while providing localized fallback. I'm also planning to add translations to validation messages like "Entry date is required" by modifying getErrors to accept the translation function and updating components to use the translation hook accordingly.

summary.text:
**Analyzing localization for default alt text and error messages**

I'm figuring out how to handle the default "Entry photo" alt text, which is stored in English but needs to appear localized in the UI without changing the stored data. My plan is to export the default alt constant and map it to translations during rendering in UI components like EntryDetail and MediaGallery, keeping data untouched while providing localized fallback. I'm also planning to add translations to validation messages like "Entry date is required" by modifying getErrors to accept the translation function and updating components to use the translation hook accordingly.

payload.text:
**Planning translation integration for error messages**

I'm figuring out how to make all UI error messages translatable, especially those from validation and upload utilities that donâ€™t directly access translation hooks. Iâ€™m considering passing a translator function down to `validateEntryMediaFile` and possibly `uploadEntryMediaBatch`, but finding simpler ways like mapping known English error strings to translation keys when rendering might be best. I want to keep changes minimal while ensuring error messages the user sees are localized, so I'll patch files incrementally and update error handling to use translations where feasible.

payload.text:
**Planning translation support for validation errors**

Iâ€™m figuring out how to keep validation functions consistent between server and client while adding optional translation support. The server will keep returning English strings since it doesnâ€™t handle locale, but client calls can pass a translator function to get localized messages. I also want to add error keys for consistent mapping and consider updating error handling in cover image uploads to support translated messages in the UI. This way, errors can remain clear and user-friendly across both environments.

summary.text:
**Planning translation support for validation errors**

Iâ€™m figuring out how to keep validation functions consistent between server and client while adding optional translation support. The server will keep returning English strings since it doesnâ€™t handle locale, but client calls can pass a translator function to get localized messages. I also want to add error keys for consistent mapping and consider updating error handling in cover image uploads to support translated messages in the UI. This way, errors can remain clear and user-friendly across both environments.

summary.text:
**Enhancing error handling in handleSubmit**

I'll add a helper function to map server validation error messages to localized user-friendly strings, then integrate it into handleSubmit to set field-specific errors or a generic form error accordingly. This keeps error feedback clear and consistent for the user.

A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/tommy/Development/TravelBlogs/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/tommy/Development/TravelBlogs/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Updating alt text handling in entry-reader and media-gallery**

I'm planning to fix how default alt text is handled in entry-reader and media-gallery by comparing alt attributes to DEFAULT_INLINE_ALT, ensuring the localized text key (`t('entries.entryPhoto')`) is used instead of the literal string "Entry photo." I'll add a helper function to cleanly resolve alt text preferences across image blocks and viewer components.

summary.text:
**Updating alt text handling in entry-reader and media-gallery**

I'm planning to fix how default alt text is handled in entry-reader and media-gallery by comparing alt attributes to DEFAULT_INLINE_ALT, ensuring the localized text key (`t('entries.entryPhoto')`) is used instead of the literal string "Entry photo." I'll add a helper function to cleanly resolve alt text preferences across image blocks and viewer components.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/tommy/Development/TravelBlogs/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/tommy/Development/TravelBlogs/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/tommy/Development/TravelBlogs/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/tommy/Development/TravelBlogs/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Evaluating translation strategy for server components**

I'm weighing how to handle translations in server components, considering client-side locale limits and server-side detection via headers. Iâ€™m thinking about creating small client header components with translation hooks or adding simple server-side locale detection using Accept-Language headers to enable server translations without full client hydration. This approach could strike a balance between translation coverage and complexity across multiple server page components.

summary.text:
**Evaluating translation strategy for server components**

I'm weighing how to handle translations in server components, considering client-side locale limits and server-side detection via headers. Iâ€™m thinking about creating small client header components with translation hooks or adding simple server-side locale detection using Accept-Language headers to enable server translations without full client hydration. This approach could strike a balance between translation coverage and complexity across multiple server page components.

payload.text:
**Summarizing extensive i18n updates and usage**

I updated numerous i18n keys across server and UI components including entries, trips, and admin sections. Translation files and several key components like entry forms, trip details, and admin pages were brought up to date with new keys. I also ensured consistent usage of translation hooks and constants like `DEFAULT_INLINE_ALT`. While tests werenâ€™t run yet, Iâ€™m ready to summarize changes and suggest running tests as a next step.

summary.text:
**Summarizing extensive i18n updates and usage**

I updated numerous i18n keys across server and UI components including entries, trips, and admin sections. Translation files and several key components like entry forms, trip details, and admin pages were brought up to date with new keys. I also ensured consistent usage of translation hooks and constants like `DEFAULT_INLINE_ALT`. While tests werenâ€™t run yet, Iâ€™m ready to summarize changes and suggest running tests as a next step.

payload.message:
Made all remaining UI strings translatable across client components and the remaining server-rendered pages, and expanded the i18n dictionary to cover new keys for trips, entries, auth, and admin copy. Added server-side locale detection from `accept-language` for pages that render text on the server, and localized upload/validation errors by threading translation helpers into media upload utilities.

Details
- Updated UI copy, aria-labels, and placeholders in entry/trip/admin/auth components to use `t(...)`, including media galleries, entry forms, trip share/invite flows, and delete modals. Key refs: `travelblogs/src/components/media/media-gallery.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/entries/entry-detail.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/entries/create-entry-form.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/entries/edit-entry-form.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/trips/trip-detail.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/admin/user-form.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/admin/user-list.tsx`.
- Localized server-rendered page headings and error states using `getTranslation` with `accept-language` detection. Key refs: `travelblogs/src/app/trips/[tripId]/entries/new/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/trips/[tripId]/entries/[entryId]/edit/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/trips/[tripId]/overview/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/trips/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/admin/users/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/entries/[id]/page.tsx`.
- Added locale helper and expanded translations (EN/DE) for all new keys, plus localized upload/validation errors for media and cover images. Key ref: `travelblogs/src/utils/i18n.ts`, `travelblogs/src/utils/entry-media.ts`, `travelblogs/src/utils/cover-upload.ts`, `travelblogs/src/utils/media.ts`.

Tests not run (not requested).

Next steps
1. Run your preferred test suite (e.g. `npm test` or `pnpm test`) to confirm no regressions.
2. Manually smoke-check key flows (sign-in, trip share/invite, entry create/edit) in both locales to confirm all strings render as expected.

Added server-side locale detection from `accept-language` for pages that render text on the server, and localized upload/validation errors by threading translation helpers into media upload utilities.

Details
- Updated UI copy, aria-labels, and placeholders in entry/trip/admin/auth components to use `t(...)`, including media galleries, entry forms, trip share/invite flows, and delete modals. Key refs: `travelblogs/src/components/media/media-gallery.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/entries/entry-detail.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/entries/create-entry-form.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/entries/edit-entry-form.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/trips/trip-detail.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/admin/user-form.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/components/admin/user-list.tsx`.
- Localized server-rendered page headings and error states using `getTranslation` with `accept-language` detection. Key refs: `travelblogs/src/app/trips/[tripId]/entries/new/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/trips/[tripId]/entries/[entryId]/edit/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/trips/[tripId]/overview/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/trips/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/admin/users/page.tsx`, `travelblogs/src/app/entries/[id]/page.tsx`.
- Added locale helper and expanded translations (EN/DE) for all new keys, plus localized upload/validation errors for media and cover images. Key ref: `travelblogs/src/utils/i18n.ts`, `travelblogs/src/utils/entry-media.ts`, `travelblogs/src/utils/cover-upload.ts`, `travelblogs/src/utils/media.ts`.

# Project Context for AI Agents

_This file contains critical rules and patterns that AI agents must follow when implementing code in this project. Focus on unobvious details that agents might otherwise miss._

---

## Technology Stack & Versions

- Next.js (create-next-app latest) + App Router
- React (via Next.js)
- TypeScript (via Next.js)
- Tailwind CSS (via Next.js setup)
- Prisma 7.2.0 (ORM + migrations)
- SQLite (primary DB)
- Auth.js (NextAuth) 4.24.13 (JWT sessions)
- Redux Toolkit 2.11.2 (state)
- Zod 4.2.1 (validation)

## Critical Implementation Rules

### Language-Specific Rules

- Use `camelCase` for variables/functions; avoid `snake_case`.
- Keep DB table names singular and Prisma model names singular.
- Use async/await for async flows; no raw Promise chains.
- API errors must use `{ error: { code, message } }`.
- Dates in JSON must be ISO 8601 strings.

### Framework-Specific Rules

- App Router only; all API routes live under `src/app/api`.
- REST endpoints are plural (`/trips`, `/entries`), params use `:id`.
- Responses must be wrapped `{ data, error }`.
- Components are `PascalCase`, files are `kebab-case.tsx`.
- Feature components live in `src/components/<feature>/`.
- Redux state slices live in `src/store/<feature>/` with actions `feature/action`.
- Use Next.js Image for media; lazy-load by default.

### Testing Rules

- Tests live in central `tests/` (no co-located tests).
- Organize tests by `tests/api`, `tests/components`, `tests/e2e`, `tests/fixtures`.
- Use the API error format in test expectations.

### Code Quality & Style Rules

- Follow naming conventions: `camelCase` vars, `PascalCase` components, `kebab-case.tsx` files.
- API response shape must be `{ data, error }` with `{ error: { code, message } }`.
- JSON fields are `camelCase`.
- Use `utils/` for shared helpers; avoid adding `lib/`.

### Development Workflow Rules

- Use `.env` and `.env.example`; no `.env.local`.
- Keep REST routes in `src/app/api` only.
- Docker and TLS proxy are post-MVP; do not add in MVP work.

### Critical Don't-Miss Rules

- Do not use `snake_case` in JSON or API params.
- Do not create singular REST endpoints (no `/trip`).
- Do not bypass `{ data, error }` response wrapper.
- Do not colocate tests with source files.
- Do not introduce Docker/TLS proxy in MVP tasks.

---

## Usage Guidelines

**For AI Agents:**

- Read this file before implementing any code
- Follow ALL rules exactly as documented
- When in doubt, prefer the more restrictive option
- Update this file if new patterns emerge

**For Humans:**

- Keep this file lean and focused on agent needs
- Update when technology stack changes
- Review quarterly for outdated rules
- Remove rules that become obvious over time

This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).

## Getting Started

First, run the development server:

```bash
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
# or
pnpm dev
# or
bun dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.

You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.

This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.

## HTTPS (Production)

TravelBlogs runs over HTTPS in production using a custom Node HTTPS entrypoint.

1. Obtain certificates from a free provider like Lets Encrypt.
2. Place the files on your NAS, for example:
   - `/volume1/certs/travelblogs/fullchain.pem`
   - `/volume1/certs/travelblogs/privkey.pem`
3. Set the env vars in `.env`:
   - `TLS_CERT_PATH=/volume1/certs/travelblogs/fullchain.pem`
   - `TLS_KEY_PATH=/volume1/certs/travelblogs/privkey.pem`
   - `TLS_CA_PATH=/volume1/certs/travelblogs/chain.pem` (optional)
4. Build and run the HTTPS server:
   - `npm run build`
   - `npm run start` (alias: `npm run start:https`)

Lets Encrypt certificates expire every 90 days. Plan regular renewals and update the files in place so the server can be restarted with fresh certs.

## Learn More

To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:

- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.

You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!

## Deploy on Vercel

The easiest way to deploy your Next.js app is to use the [Vercel Platform](https://vercel.com/new?utm_medium=default-template&filter=next.js&utm_source=create-next-app&utm_campaign=create-next-app-readme) from the creators of Next.js.

Check out our [Next.js deployment documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/deploying) for more details.
